trial_identification.studytitle: Tyrosine supplementation in preventing the cognitive effects of psychosocial stress
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Tyrosine supplementation versus placebo in preventing the cognitive effects of psychosocial stress in healthy adults

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of normal psychology, cognitive function and behaviour

interventions.interventions: Once off administration of an oral solution containing either the natural amino acid tyrosine (at a dose of either 100mg/kg or 200mg/kg) or a placebo to healthy adult (male and female) volunteers, two hours prior to exposure to psychosocial stressor (Trier Social Stress Test). To be administered randomly and in a blinded manner

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in neurocognition as measured by neurocogntive tests battery including simple and choice reaction time, verbal episodic memory, groton maze learning task
primaryOutcome.timepoint: To be measured during one day of testing - at baseline, immediately following administration of Trier Social Stress Test and again one hour later

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in biochemical markers of stress (salivary cortisol and alpha-amylase) and central dopamine activity (serum prolactin)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: To be measured during one day of testing - at baseline, immediately pre- and post-administration of Trier Social Stress Test and again one hour later

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Past or present mental illness Family history of mental illness Any medication or illicit substance use Pregnant

trial_design.concealment: Allocation concealed through the use of an "off-site" allocation schedule. The holder of the schedule contacted following enrollment of a subject
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a randomisation table created by a computer

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Department of Psychiatry University of Melbourne Austin Health 145 Studley Rd Heidelberg Victoria 3084

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
This study aims to evaluate the effects of the administration of the natural amino acid, tyrosine, compared with that of a placebo on the cognitive functioning of healthy adult volunteers subjected to an acute psychosocial stress event.
This is based on the hypothesis that pre-test administration with tyrosine will prevent or reduce the negative impact of psychosocial stress on a broad range of cognitive tasks through its effect on neurotransmitter functioning
